rule_checks.loc: p.1, Instructions ("All fields must be completed unless otherwise noted")
rule_checks.criteria_text: Standalone Energization Request form requires all fields completed and ERCOT approval prior to energization; incomplete submissions can delay the process.

rule_checks.loc: p.3, "How does ERCOT define a large load?"
rule_checks.criteria_text: A Large Load is one or more facilities at a single site with aggregate peak demand ≥ 75 MW behind common POI.

rule_checks.loc: p.4, Section 9.2.1 Applicability
rule_checks.criteria_text: Planning Guide Section 9 applies to new Large Loads, load increases ≥75 MW, or POI relocation to a different bus/circuit.

rule_checks.loc: p.1, Overview ("peak demand of 75 MW or more at a single site")
rule_checks.criteria_text: Large Load Interconnection Process is framed around a single-site large load. If multiple POIs/sites are being considered, treat them as separate screening tracks and expect additional coordination/study overhead.

rule_checks.loc: p.2, Overview ("applied to both stand-alone large load customers and those co-locating with existing or planned generation")
rule_checks.criteria_text: Large Load Interconnection Process explicitly includes large loads co-locating with existing or planned generation; such configurations can increase coordination and study dependency in screening.

rule_checks.loc: pp.2–4, Overview (Texas SB6 Net Metering Review; "net metering arrangement"; "must also obtain approval" before load can be energized)
rule_checks.criteria_text: If an export/net-metering posture is contemplated (often implying co-located generation/storage), a Net Metering Review may apply; for certain arrangements involving existing stand-alone Generation/ESR, approval through the Net Metering Review is required before the load can be energized (bounded screening signal).

rule_checks.loc: p.6, "initiate the Large Load Interconnection Process?"
rule_checks.criteria_text: Large Load interconnection begins with submission to the responsible TSP including peak demand and requested energization date.

rule_checks.loc: p.7, Planning Guide Section 9.2.2
rule_checks.criteria_text: Interconnecting Large Load must provide a preliminary Load Commissioning Plan specifying load increments and timeline to peak demand.

rule_checks.loc: p.7, Planning Guide Section 9.2.2 fee requirement
rule_checks.criteria_text: Large Load must pay an ERCOT application fee in addition to TSP fees.

rule_checks.loc: p.7, Planning Guide Section 9.2.3
rule_checks.criteria_text: Material project changes (load type, timeline acceleration, POI change, control changes) may require full or partial re-study.

rule_checks.loc: p.8–9, "What types of reliability studies are required?"
rule_checks.criteria_text: Required studies include steady-state, dynamic/transient stability, and system protection (short-circuit) analysis.

rule_checks.loc: p.10–11, Planning Guide Section 9.3.4.1
rule_checks.criteria_text: A load becomes must-study after completion of LLIS and execution of required agreements and financial security.

rule_checks.loc: p.13, Planning Guide Sections 9.5–9.6
rule_checks.criteria_text: Before energization, all LLIS studies must be completed, agreements executed, financial security provided, and commissioning plan submitted.

rule_checks.loc: p.12–13, "Network Operations Model"
rule_checks.criteria_text: Load must be included in ERCOT Network Operations Model before energization.

rule_checks.loc: p.14–15, "voltage and frequency ride-through risks"
rule_checks.criteria_text: Large Electronic Loads must meet voltage and frequency ride-through standards or may be subject to curtailment.

rule_checks.loc: p.15, Planning Guide Section 9.4(10)
rule_checks.criteria_text: If energization requirements are not met within 365 days of requested energization date used for LLIS, TSP must determine whether re-studies are required.

rule_checks.loc: p.16, Planning Guide Sections 9.2.2 & 9.6
rule_checks.criteria_text: Large load must maintain consumption within Load Commissioning Plan limits; exceeding requires notification and approval.

rule_checks.loc: Section 1.1, p.1
rule_checks.criteria_text: Applies to interconnections at transmission voltages (69 kV and higher).

rule_checks.loc: Section 3.4.1, p.3
rule_checks.criteria_text: Transmission voltages are 69 kV, 138 kV, and 345 kV. Not all voltages may be available at a given location.

rule_checks.loc: Section 3.4.1, p.3 ("The actual voltage for a Point of Delivery will be determined through analyses"; "Not all voltages may be available")
rule_checks.criteria_text: If both 138 kV and 345 kV are being considered as options, the actual POD voltage must be determined through Company analyses and availability may constrain choices.

rule_checks.loc: Section 3.4.1, p.3 ("The actual voltage for a Point of Delivery will be determined through analyses"; "Not all voltages may be available")
rule_checks.criteria_text: If both 69 kV and 138 kV are being considered as options, the actual POD voltage must be determined through Company analyses and availability may constrain choices.

rule_checks.loc: Section 3.4.1, p.3 ("The actual voltage for a Point of Delivery will be determined through analyses"; "Not all voltages may be available")
rule_checks.criteria_text: If both 69 kV and 345 kV are being considered as options, the actual POD voltage must be determined through Company analyses and availability may constrain choices.

rule_checks.loc: Section 4.1.8, p.6
rule_checks.criteria_text: Customer must provide initial and five-year load projections including peak load power factor.

rule_checks.loc: Section 4.1.6, p.6
rule_checks.criteria_text: Customer must submit a one-line electrical diagram of proposed facilities (initial and ultimate).

rule_checks.loc: Section 5.2.1, p.7
rule_checks.criteria_text: Customer protective equipment must be fully rated to interrupt available fault current.

rule_checks.loc: Section 3.6.1, p.3–4
rule_checks.criteria_text: Metering of service at each Point of Delivery is required.

rule_checks.loc: Section 3.3.2, p.3
rule_checks.criteria_text: ERCOT approval via NOMCR process is required before connecting new or modified transmission facilities.

rule_checks.loc: p.3, "may not proceed until written approval"
rule_checks.criteria_text: Initial energization may not proceed until written approval of the form is given by ERCOT.

sources.loc: PDF p.3 (written approval required before energization)

evidence: ERCOT written approval of the Energization Request form prior to energization (form p.3)
Signed/attested Energization Request form submitted to ERCOT (form p.3)
memo_guidance.what_to_do: Submit the Energization Request form and obtain ERCOT written approval before proceeding to initial energization.

rule_checks.loc: p.1, "already energized are covered by a different form"
rule_checks.criteria_text: Form applies to new energizations only; peak demand increases require a different form.

rule_checks.loc: p.2, "All studies required per the Large Load Interconnection Study process have been completed and approved"
rule_checks.criteria_text: All studies required per the LLIS process must be completed and approved per Planning Guide Section 9.4.

sources.loc: PDF p.2 (TSP confirms LLIS studies completed and approved by ERCOT)

evidence: Energization Request form attestation that all required LLIS studies have been completed and approved by ERCOT (form p.2)
memo_guidance.what_to_do: Confirm all LLIS studies are completed and approved by ERCOT before requesting energization approval.

rule_checks.loc: p.2, "Is a SSO study required for this Large Load interconnection?"
rule_checks.criteria_text: Confirm whether an SSO study is required for this project (v0 input). If required, the SSO completion gate applies.

rule_checks.loc: p.2, "The SSO study is complete and all required mitigation is in place"
rule_checks.criteria_text: If an SSO study is required, it must be complete and mitigation must be in place before energization.

sources.loc: PDF p.2 (SSO required? If yes, SSO study complete and mitigation operational)

evidence: Energization Request form: SSO required? and (if yes) confirmation that the SSO study is complete and required mitigation is in place/operational (form p.2)
memo_guidance.what_to_do: If an SSO study is required, complete the SSO study and ensure required mitigation is in place and operational before energization.

rule_checks.loc: p.2, "Large Electronic Load (LEL)"
rule_checks.criteria_text: If facility is a Large Electronic Load (LEL), it must be included in ERCOT interim ride-through assessment.

sources.loc: PDF p.2 (LEL: included in ERCOT interim ride-through assessment)

evidence: Energization Request form: if facility is a Large Electronic Load (LEL), confirmation that it has been included in an ERCOT interim ride-through assessment (form p.2)
memo_guidance.what_to_do: If the facility is a Large Electronic Load (LEL), ensure it is included in the required ERCOT interim ride-through assessment before energization.

rule_checks.loc: p.2, "All required interconnection agreements"
rule_checks.criteria_text: All interconnection agreements must be executed and financial security posted per Planning Guide Section 9.5.1.

sources.loc: PDF p.2 (agreements executed and financial security posted)
PDF p.2 (form states agreements/security per Planning Guide Section 9.5.1)

evidence: Energization Request form: confirmation that required interconnection/service agreements are executed and required financial security has been posted (form p.2)
memo_guidance.what_to_do: Ensure required interconnection/service agreements are executed and required financial security is posted before requesting energization approval.

rule_checks.loc: p.2, "no changes have been made to the load composition"
rule_checks.criteria_text: ILLE must confirm no substantial changes in load composition or parameters from dynamic model used in LLIS Stability Study.

sources.loc: PDF p.2 (written acknowledgement from ILLE: no substantial changes vs dynamic model)

evidence: Written acknowledgement from the ILLE that no substantial changes have been made vs the dynamic model used in the LLIS Stability Study (form p.2)
Energization Request form attestation that the interconnecting TSP has received this acknowledgement (form p.2)
memo_guidance.what_to_do: Obtain the ILLE's written acknowledgement that no substantial changes have been made vs the dynamic model assumptions used in the LLIS stability study.

rule_checks.loc: p.2, "included in the Network Operations Model"
rule_checks.criteria_text: Large Load must be included in the ERCOT Network Operations Model before energization.

sources.loc: PDF p.2 (NOM included; provide NOMCR # / Production Load Date / Maximum MW Modeled)
PDF p.3 (written approval required before energization)

evidence: Completed Energization Request form NOM section (NOMCR #, Production Load Date, Maximum MW Modeled) (form p.2)
ERCOT written approval of the Energization Request form (form p.3)
memo_guidance.what_to_do: Confirm the Large Load is included in the Network Operations Model (NOM) and provide the NOMCR details as part of the Energization Request prior to energization.

rule_checks.loc: p.2, "Disturbance Monitoring Equipment (DME) is required"
rule_checks.criteria_text: Confirm whether ERCOT requires Disturbance Monitoring Equipment (DME) for this project (v0 input). If required, the DME installation gate applies.

rule_checks.loc: p.2, "Is the DME installed and configured?"
rule_checks.criteria_text: If ERCOT requires Disturbance Monitoring Equipment (DME), it must be installed and operational.

sources.loc: PDF p.2 (DME required? If yes, installed/configured and provide operational date)

evidence: Energization Request form: ERCOT notification whether DME is required; if required, confirmation DME installed/configured and projected operational date (form p.2)
memo_guidance.what_to_do: If ERCOT requires DME for the facility, install/configure the DME and document the operational date as part of the Energization Request.

rule_checks.loc: p.2, "All required telemetry required by the ERCOT Protocols"
rule_checks.criteria_text: All required telemetry per ERCOT Protocols must be operational and accurate before energization.

sources.loc: PDF p.2 (telemetry operational/accurate as-of date)
PDF p.1 (telemetry contact fields)

evidence: Energization Request form: telemetry operational/accurate as-of date (form p.2)
Telemetry contact fields on the Energization Request form (form p.1)
memo_guidance.what_to_do: Confirm all required telemetry is operational and accurate and record the as-of date on the Energization Request.

rule_checks.loc: p.129, Section 9.2.2(1)(b) ("Submission of a preliminary Load Commissioning Plan (LCP)")
rule_checks.criteria_text: Prior to initiation of LLIS, the ILLE must submit a preliminary Load Commissioning Plan (LCP) that fully reflects the project schedule (Planning Guide Section 9.2.2(1)(b)).

rule_checks.loc: p.129, Section 9.2.2(1)(c) ("Written acknowledgement from the Interconnecting Large Load Entity (ILLE)")
rule_checks.criteria_text: Prior to initiation of LLIS, written acknowledgement from the ILLE of obligations (including notification of project changes per Section 9.2.3) is required (Planning Guide Section 9.2.2(1)(c)).

rule_checks.loc: p.129, Section 9.2.2(1)(d) ("A formal request to initiate the LLIS process")
rule_checks.criteria_text: Prior to initiation of LLIS, a formal request to initiate the LLIS process is required (Planning Guide Section 9.2.2(1)(d)).

rule_checks.loc: p.130, Section 9.2.2(1)(e) ("Payment of the LLIS Application Fee")
rule_checks.criteria_text: Prior to commencement of LLIS, the ILLE shall pay the LLIS Application Fee to ERCOT (Planning Guide Section 9.2.2(1)(e)).

rule_checks.loc: p.132, Section 9.3.1(4) ("interconnecting at distribution voltage"; "LLIS shall evaluate only ... transmission-level impacts"; "DSP shall provide ... information")
rule_checks.criteria_text: For a Large Load interconnecting at distribution voltage, the LLIS evaluates only transmission-level impacts (if any) and requires coordination/input from the affected DSP to complete required studies.

rule_checks.loc: p.131, Section 9.2.5(1) ("interconnected at transmission voltage"; "must have ... breakers capable of interrupting fault current"; "remote control" by TO)
rule_checks.criteria_text: Each Service Delivery Point for a Large Load (not co-located) interconnected at transmission voltage must have a permanent configuration with breakers capable of interrupting fault current to isolate the Large Load without interrupting flow on associated transmission lines, under remote control of the applicable Transmission Operator.

rule_checks.loc: p.131, Section 9.2.5(2) ("co-located"; "breakers ... isolate the Large Load ... without isolating any of the co-located generators"; "direction of the QSE")
rule_checks.criteria_text: Each Large Load co-located with a Generation Resource/ESR/SOG and interconnected at transmission voltage must have a permanent breaker configuration capable of isolating the Large Load without isolating co-located generators; breakers must be remotely controllable at the direction of the applicable QSE.

rule_checks.loc: p.132, Section 9.3.1(4) ("distribution voltage"; "DSP shall provide ... information")
rule_checks.criteria_text: For distribution-voltage Large Load interconnections, the affected DSP must provide the lead TSP with facility information needed to complete required studies (Planning Guide Section 9.3.1(4)).

rule_checks.loc: p.131, Section 9.2.5(1)-(2) ("interconnected at transmission voltage"; breaker configuration; remote control by TO / direction of QSE)
rule_checks.criteria_text: For transmission-voltage Large Load interconnections, confirm the required permanent breaker configuration is in place/confirmed (Planning Guide Section 9.2.5).

sources.loc: PDF p.131, Section 9.2.5(1)-(2) (Required interconnection equipment; breaker configuration; remote control)

evidence: One-line / switching diagram showing the permanent breaker configuration at the Service Delivery Point(s) (PG Section 9.2.5)
Confirmation that breakers are capable of interrupting fault current and are remotely controllable as required (PG Section 9.2.5)
memo_guidance.what_to_do: Confirm and document the required transmission-voltage breaker configuration (fault interruption + remote control) per Planning Guide Section 9.2.5.

rule_checks.loc: p.130, Section 9.2.3 ("within ten Business Days")
rule_checks.criteria_text: After notification of a material change, the lead TSP updates submitted project information within ten Business Days (Planning Guide Section 9.2.3).

rule_checks.loc: p.130, Section 9.2.3 ("dynamic model information used in the LLIS stability study")
rule_checks.criteria_text: A material change to information used in the LLIS stability study dynamic model can impact study assumptions and trigger re-evaluation (Planning Guide Section 9.2.3).

rule_checks.loc: p.131, Section 9.2.4(2) ("Upon the completion of the LLIS")
rule_checks.criteria_text: Upon completion of the LLIS, the LCP is updated to reflect LLIS results (Planning Guide Section 9.2.4(2)).

rule_checks.loc: p.135, Section 9.3.4.1 ("9.3.4.1 Steady-State Analysis")
rule_checks.criteria_text: The LLIS includes a Steady-State Analysis element (Planning Guide Section 9.3.4.1).

rule_checks.loc: p.136, Section 9.3.4.2 ("System Protection (Short-Circuit) Analysis")
rule_checks.criteria_text: The LLIS includes a System Protection (Short-Circuit) Analysis element (Planning Guide Section 9.3.4.2).

rule_checks.loc: p.136, Section 9.3.4.3 ("Dynamic and Transient Stability Analysis")
rule_checks.criteria_text: The LLIS includes a Dynamic and Transient Stability Analysis element (Planning Guide Section 9.3.4.3).

rule_checks.criteria_text: Initial Energization prerequisites include inclusion of the Load in the Network Operations Model (Planning Guide Section 9.6(a)).

rule_checks.criteria_text: Prior to initiation of the LLIS process, submission of the study data package required by the lead TSP (steady state, short-circuit, motor start, stability inputs and other necessary data) is required (Planning Guide Section 9.2.2(1)(a)).

rule_checks.loc: p.130, Section 9.2.3(2) ("The ILLE shall notify the lead TSP if a change to the load composition, technology, or parameters occurs")
rule_checks.criteria_text: If a material change to load composition/technology/parameters occurs after initial dynamic load model submission, the ILLE shall notify the lead TSP (Planning Guide Section 9.2.3(2)).

rule_checks.loc: p.130, Section 9.2.3(2) ("the lead TSP shall determine whether a new stability study is required and provide a written explanation")
rule_checks.criteria_text: If post-initiation changes differ substantially from the dynamic model information used in the LLIS stability study, the lead TSP shall determine whether a new stability study is required and provide a written explanation to ERCOT (Planning Guide Section 9.2.3(2)).

rule_checks.loc: p.131, Section 9.2.4(1) ("The LCP must specify the load increments and timeline by which the ILLE intends to increase peak Demand")
rule_checks.criteria_text: When a phased energization plan is used in screening, the LCP must specify load increments and timeline; v0 models this as providing a phased schedule (phases) consistent with the LCP (Planning Guide Section 9.2.4(1)).

rule_checks.loc: p.138, Section 9.4(9) ("If the requirements of Section 9.5, have not been satisfied within 180 days after the communication of the completion of the LLIS")
rule_checks.criteria_text: If Section 9.5 requirements are not satisfied within 180 days after ERCOT communication of LLIS completion, the project may be subject to cancellation; in v0 this is flagged when agreements are known to be not executed post-LLIS (Planning Guide Section 9.4(9)).

rule_checks.loc: p.138, Section 9.4(9) ("If the requirements of Section 9.5, have not been satisfied within 180 days after the communication of the completion of the LLIS")
rule_checks.criteria_text: If Section 9.5 requirements are not satisfied within 180 days after ERCOT communication of LLIS completion, the project may be subject to cancellation; in v0 this is flagged when financial security is known to be not posted post-LLIS (Planning Guide Section 9.4(9)).

rule_checks.loc: p.138, Section 9.4(10) ("within 365 days after the Initial Energization date identified in the LLIS study report, the lead TSP shall provide an opinion to ERCOT on whether any of the completed LLIS elements require restudy")
rule_checks.criteria_text: If Initial Energization requirements are not met within 365 days after the Initial Energization date identified in the LLIS study report, the lead TSP provides an opinion on whether completed LLIS elements require restudy; ERCOT may require updates prior to approval (Planning Guide Section 9.4(10)).

rule_checks.loc: p.141, Section 9.6(1)(c) ("Completion of the requirements of Section 5.3.5, ERCOT Quarterly Stability Assessment")
rule_checks.criteria_text: Initial Energization prerequisites may include completion of ERCOT Quarterly Stability Assessment (QSA) requirements when applicable (Planning Guide Section 9.6(1)(c)).

rule_checks.loc: p.139, Section 9.5.1(iii) ("The interconnecting TSP has received notice to proceed with the construction of all required interconnection Facilities")
rule_checks.criteria_text: As part of Section 9.5.1 prerequisites, the interconnecting TSP has received notice to proceed with construction of all required interconnection facilities (Planning Guide Section 9.5.1(iii)).

rule_checks.loc: ERCOT-Large-Load-Batch-Study-Workshop-02032026.pptx, Slide 5 (background) and Slide 8 (batch process overview); PUCT Open Meeting presentation planned for 2026-02-20.
rule_checks.criteria_text: ERCOT is replacing the current individualized TSP-led LLIS model with an ERCOT-led Batch Study Process. The framework — presented at the Feb 3 2026 workshop and submitted to PUCT at the Feb 20 Open Meeting — is still preliminary and subject to change (Slide 2). The transitional Batch Zero process (Zero A and Zero B) will handle all projects currently in queue; Batch 1+ (every 6 months) will apply to new entrants. Projects entering the study process now must monitor PUCT rule 58481 finalization and ERCOT batch admission criteria. TIME ANCHORS (source: Workshop Slides 22, 24, 12-13; preliminary per Slide 2 disclaimer): Batch Zero A — case conditioning Feb–Mar 31 2026, study results communicated by Jun 15 2026; Batch Zero B — case conditioning Jun 1–Sept 1 2026, results by Jan 15 2027; Ongoing Batch 1+ — 6-month cadence (Timeline 1: results Jul 31; Timeline 2: results Jan 31); missing a batch cycle adds approximately 6 months to the study completion date.

rule_checks.loc: ERCOT-Large-Load-Batch-Study-Workshop-02032026.pptx, Slide 12-13 (Ongoing Batch Study Timeline Considerations; 6-month cadence).
rule_checks.criteria_text: The Batch Study Process runs on a 6-month cadence (Workshop Slide 12-13). Two annual cycles: Timeline 1 — case conditioning Jan 1–Apr 1, results communicated Jul 31, IA deadline Aug 31; Timeline 2 — Jul 1–Oct 1, results Jan 31, IA deadline Feb 28. If batch_cycle_window is known (e.g., "2026Q3" = Timeline 2), the memo can advise on the specific intake deadline and commitment date. Missing a cycle adds ~6 months. TIME ANCHORS for batch_cycle_window interpretation (source: Workshop Slide 13; preliminary per Slide 2 disclaimer): if a project targets Timeline 1 of a given year, the study results date is Jul 31 of that year and the IA commitment deadline is Aug 31; if it targets Timeline 2, the study results date is Jan 31 of the following year and the IA commitment deadline is Feb 28. Example: a project entering Timeline 2 of 2026 (batch_cycle_window='2026-H2') receives results by Jan 31 2027 with IA deadline Feb 28 2027. A project that misses Timeline 2 of 2026 must wait for Timeline 1 of 2027 (results Jul 31 2027), adding approximately 6 months.

rule_checks.loc: ERCOT-Large-Load-Batch-Study-Workshop-02032026.pptx, Slide 15-16 (Batch Zero is a bridge; Zero A qualification criteria).
rule_checks.criteria_text: Batch Zero A includes a "firm" path (no load allocation assessment) for projects that: (a) are operational/approved to energize (~8.2 GW), (b) were exempt from interim LLI and included in RPG/RTP study with energization before Oct 1 2027 (~17.4 GW), (c) met approved SS study + IA by Dec 15 2025 (~4.7 GW), or (d) completed PG 9.4 and 9.5 before Jan 28 2026 (~8.5 GW). If batch_zero_eligible=true, the project enters Zero A as firm load (no allocation reduction risk). If batch_zero_eligible=false or null, the project enters as "subject to load allocation" or must reapply for Batch 1.

rule_checks.loc: ERCOT-Large-Load-Batch-Study-Workshop-02032026.pptx, Slide 2 (disclaimer), Slide 47-48 (next steps); PUCT Open Meeting 2026-02-20.
rule_checks.criteria_text: As of Feb 26 2026, the Batch Study framework has been presented to PUCT at the Feb 20 Open Meeting but is still preliminary (Slide 2 disclaimer: "All information included in this presentation is preliminary and subject to change"). Workshop #3 is scheduled today. Current LLI process (Planning Guide Section 9) remains in effect. Projects should follow PG Sec 9 until ERCOT announces formal transition date (Slide 47).

rule_checks.loc: ERCOT-Large-Load-Batch-Study-Workshop-02032026.pptx, Slide 36-37 (Load Allocation Methodology — SCOPF-based); Slide 16 (Zero A/B capacity by sub-batch).
rule_checks.criteria_text: Under the Batch Study Process, load allocation is determined by Security Constrained Optimal Power Flow (SCOPF), not by queue position. ERCOT assigns dispatch costs to load requests and runs SCOPF to minimize constraint violations (Slide 36). Projects with higher shift factors on constrained elements receive lower allocations. Once queue_position is known relative to the batch, the memo can assess relative exposure. Load allocation can be reduced from prior allocations if commitment requirements (PUCT 58481 IA) are not met by the next batch start.

rule_checks.loc: p.1, M-A022326-01 – LONG DESCRIPTION: "Effective immediately, ERCOT requires TSPs to include a no-solar scenario as part of LLIS for Large Loads proposing to interconnect within the list of counties identified in this Market Notice."
rule_checks.criteria_text: ERCOT market notice M-A022326-01 requires TSPs to include a no-solar scenario as part of LLIS for Large Loads in the Far West Texas identified counties. This constraint applies only to projects with a Far West Texas POI (request.region=far_west) and results in more conservative study outcomes — higher identified upgrade costs and longer resolution timelines.

rule_checks.loc: p.1, M-A022326-01 – LONG DESCRIPTION: "ERCOT considers the identification of this risk to be a material change that impacts one or more LLIS study assumptions for interconnection requests in the identified counties." Per PG §9.4(8).
rule_checks.criteria_text: For Far West Texas projects (region=far_west): ERCOT study assumptions include the no-solar regional generation mix scenario. If the assumed generation fleet changes materially during or after the study period (e.g., additional solar retires or new thermal resources are added), study results may need to be revisited under updated assumptions. ERCOT explicitly treated the no-solar scenario identification as a material change per PG §9.4(8).

rule_checks.loc: p.1, PUCT Project No. 58481, docket filing (Sierra Club comments on 2nd Discussion Draft, 16 TAC §25.194, Jan 9 2026 workshop); rulemaking ongoing
rule_checks.criteria_text: PUCT Project No. 58481 is an active rulemaking proceeding that may result in changes to the regulatory framework governing Large Load Interconnection in Texas. Projects with long timelines should monitor this proceeding; final rules may modify planning obligations, fees, or process steps not yet reflected in the current Planning Guide.

rule_checks.loc: p.1-3, PUCT Project No. 58481, docket (16 TAC §25.194) — rulemaking establishing new interconnection standards for large loads; corroborated by ERCOT Q&A Rev.12.15.25 ("PUC is in the process of establishing new interconnection standards for large loads in Project No. 58481")
rule_checks.criteria_text: Pending PUCT regulatory changes may alter Large Load interconnection obligations including but not limited to: study timelines, fee structures, agreement terms, and TSP responsibilities. Projects in early-stage planning should explicitly track PUCT Project 58481 for potential impacts to their interconnection schedule.

rule_checks.loc: Rev.12.15.25, p.14 ("PUC is in the process of establishing new interconnection standards for large loads in Project No. 58481. That rulemaking could require changes to ERCOT's large load interconnection process and delay projects that must meet new requirements.")
rule_checks.criteria_text: Under Texas SB6 and the revised Large Load Q&A (Rev. 12.15.25): if an export/net-metering arrangement is contemplated, approval through the Net Metering Review is required before the load can be energized. This requirement applies to certain co-located arrangements with existing or planned generation/ESR (bounded screening signal; final applicability depends on metering arrangements).

rule_checks.loc: p.1, M-A122325-01 (batch study process announcement, Dec 23 2025; PGRR115 already insufficient; batch study as successor framework)
rule_checks.criteria_text: ERCOT announced on Dec 23, 2025 (M-A122325-01) that PGRR115, implemented Dec 15, 2025, is already insufficient to manage the volume of large load requests. ERCOT is developing a new "Batch Study process" as a successor framework. Projects submitted after this announcement should be evaluated against the batch study timeline and process rules rather than the pre-batch LLIS process alone.

rule_checks.loc: Rev.12.15.25, p.2 ("The interim process has applied to both stand-alone large load customers and those co-locating with existing or planned generation.")
rule_checks.criteria_text: The revised Large Load Q&A (Rev. 12.15.25) continues to explicitly include co-located loads (with existing or planned generation) within the LLIS applicability scope. Co-located configurations carry elevated coordination and study dependency.

rule_checks.loc: Slide 5-7, ERCOT-Large-Load-Batch-Studies-LLWG_01222026.pptx (Slide 5: Transitional Batch Zero and restudy context; Slide 7: TSP role changes impacting in-progress LLI requests during batch transition)
rule_checks.criteria_text: Under the proposed batch study process, a material change to an in-queue project (e.g., POI change, load increase, timeline acceleration) may cause the project to be re-slotted into a subsequent batch cycle rather than being re-studied individually. This can compound timeline delays beyond what the current individualized re-study framework implies.

rule_checks.loc: p.1, M-A122325-01 – LONG DESCRIPTION: structural challenges including "coordination across TSPs, repeated restudies, and a growing backlog." Also corroborated by Q&A Rev.12.15.25 p.10: "A common reason re-studies are needed is that another large load customer in the same area becomes a must-study load."
rule_checks.criteria_text: Under the batch study framework, the entry of a large number of must-study projects in the same geographic cohort can delay all cohort members simultaneously – analogous to the existing re-study risk in the individualized process (LL_QA_010) but potentially affecting larger groups of projects at once.

rule_checks.loc: p.1, M-A122325-03 (Jan 30, 2026): draft framework posted for Feb 3 workshop; feedback deadline Feb 5; sets up Feb 12 second workshop; framework to be filed at Feb 20 PUC Open Meeting.
rule_checks.criteria_text: ERCOT market notice series M-A122325 (notices -01 through -05) collectively announce the policy direction toward a Batch Study Process. Individually, each notice may update process details, timelines, or requirements. Projects should track the full series to avoid acting on superseded notice provisions.

rule_checks.loc: p.1, M-A122325-05 (Feb 17, 2026): "PUC recently provided guidance to ERCOT and stakeholders to engage in an expedited process to develop revision requests that create a new Batch Zero study for consideration at the June 1, 2026 ERCOT Board meeting."
rule_checks.criteria_text: ERCOT Market Notice M-A122325-05 is the latest in the M-A122325 series as of 2026-02-26. It may contain the most current batch study process details, timelines, or eligibility criteria announced prior to the final rule. Projects assessing study timeline risk should reference this notice for the most recent ERCOT policy position.

rule_checks.loc: p.1, M-A122325-01 (context: public reporting of ERCOT shift to data-center batch study framework)
rule_checks.criteria_text: ERCOT is transitioning from individualized Large Load studies to a batch study process, partly in response to a surge in data center and large-load interconnection requests. This macro shift means projects submitted in the near term may face a different study process than projects submitted under the current framework, creating planning uncertainty for any project with a 2026-2028 energization target.

rule_checks.loc: p.1, M-A022326-01 – LONG DESCRIPTION: "ERCOT will not approve LLIS studies for Large Load additions in the Far West unless they include a no-solar scenario." Counties: Andrews, Borden, Brewster, Coke, Concho, Crane, Crockett, Culberson, Dawson, Ector, Edwards, Fisher, Glasscock, Howard, Irion, Jeff Davis, Jones, Kinney, Loving, Lynn, Martin, Midland, Mitchell, Nolan, Pecos, Presidio, Reagan, Reeves, Schleicher, Scurry, Sterling, Sutton, Terrell, Tom Green, Upton, Val Verde, Ward, Winkler.
rule_checks.criteria_text: For Far West Texas projects (region=far_west): the no-solar scenario constraint typically produces higher identified upgrade costs and longer resolution timelines compared to projects in other ERCOT zones — even for similar load sizes and configurations. This is a direct consequence of M-A022326-01 requirements.

rule_checks.loc: p.1, M-A022326-01 – ACTION REQUIRED: "TSPs for Large Loads requesting to interconnect within the identified counties that have LLIS studies that are not started or are currently in progress, as well as studies approved under §9.4 but where ILLE has not met §9.5 requirements as of 2026-02-23, must update the study to include a no-solar scenario."
rule_checks.criteria_text: For Far West Texas projects (region=far_west) where LLIS is already complete: ERCOT study results may be conditional on the no-solar scenario. If ILLE has not yet met §9.5 requirements as of 2026-02-23, the study must be updated per M-A022326-01. Even after §9.5 satisfaction, system-level assumption changes (new or retired regional generation) could trigger restudy before energization.

rule_checks.loc: p.1, PUCT Project No. 58481, docket (Sierra Club comments reference 50% backup generation threshold, SB 6 compliance, and large load qualification standards under 16 TAC §25.194)
rule_checks.criteria_text: Pending PUCT rulemaking under Project 58481 may modify energization prerequisites, TSP/ILLE obligations, or ERCOT approval authority for Large Load projects. Projects targeting energization in 2026-2028 should confirm that their energization checklist reflects any adopted rule changes before finalizing the readiness assessment.

rule_checks.loc: ERCOT-Large-Load-Batch-Study-Workshop-02032026.pptx, Slide 16 (Batch Zero A and Zero B qualification and anticipated capacity); Slide 18 (Inclusion Criteria for Batch Zero A).
rule_checks.criteria_text: Batch Zero A qualification (Slide 18): A project is included as FIRM (no allocation assessment) if it: (a) is operational or approved to energize (~8,223 MW); (b) was exempt from interim LLI process and included in RPG/RTP study with energization before Oct 1, 2027 (~17,437 MW); (c) met approved steady-state study + signed IA to be designated 'must study' under interim LLI process before Dec 15, 2025 (~4,666 MW); or (d) fulfilled PG 9.4 (all LLIS studies complete) and PG 9.5 (agreements, financial security, NTP) before Jan 28, 2026 (~8,471 MW). Projects that have started LLI study process but do not meet the above criteria are NOT included in Batch Zero A (~59,411 MW affected). batch_zero_eligible=true indicates the project qualifies as firm; batch_zero_eligible=false means it must enter as 'subject to load allocation' in Zero B or reapply for Batch 1.

rule_checks.loc: ERCOT-Large-Load-Batch-Study-Workshop-02032026.pptx, Slide 19-24 (Batch Zero B inclusion criteria; Slide 22 Zero A timeline; Slide 24 Zero B timeline).
rule_checks.criteria_text: Batch Zero B timeline (Slide 24): Case conditioning Jun 1–Sept 1 2026. Deadline for LLI to meet 58481 intermediate agreement requirements: Aug 1 2026. Results communicated Jan 15 2027. Deadline for ILLE to meet 58481 interconnection agreement requirements for load allocation to be firm in Batch 1: Feb 28 2027. Batch Zero A results deadline: Jun 15 2026 (Slide 22). Deadline for firm allocation in Batch Zero B: Aug 1 2026 (IA required). If a project's batch_zero_eligible=false and it has a COD target in 2027 or later, it must meet the 58481 intermediate agreement requirements before Aug 1 2026 to be included in Batch Zero B as 'subject to load allocation'; otherwise it must reapply for Batch 1. TIME ANCHORS — minimum study timeline floor by scenario (source: Slides 22, 24; all dates preliminary per Slide 2 disclaimer): (1) batch_zero_eligible=true → study results by Jun 15 2026 (Batch Zero A), floor from today (2026-02-27) ≈ 4 months to study results; add 6–12 months for agreements + NTP + NOM → earliest realistic energization floor ≈ late 2026 to early 2027. (2) batch_zero_eligible=false, IA submitted before Aug 1 2026 → study results Jan 15 2027 (Batch Zero B), floor ≈ 10.5 months to study results; add 6–12 months → earliest realistic energization floor ≈ mid to late 2027. (3) batch_zero_eligible=false, IA not submitted before Aug 1 2026 → must enter Batch 1 (Timeline 1 2027: results Jul 31 2027, or Timeline 2 2027: results Jan 31 2028); floor ≈ 17–23 months to study results; add 6–12 months → earliest realistic energization floor ≈ 2028 or later. These floors are study-process floors only; transmission upgrade construction timelines (if triggered) extend COD further and are not captured here.

rule_checks.loc: p.1, Instructions ("All fields must be completed unless otherwise noted")
rule_checks.criteria_text: Standalone Energization Request form requires all fields completed and ERCOT approval prior to energization; incomplete submissions can delay the process.

rule_checks.loc: p.3, "How does ERCOT define a large load?"
rule_checks.criteria_text: A Large Load is one or more facilities at a single site with aggregate peak demand ≥ 75 MW behind common POI.

rule_checks.loc: p.4, Section 9.2.1 Applicability
rule_checks.criteria_text: Planning Guide Section 9 applies to new Large Loads, load increases ≥75 MW, or POI relocation to a different bus/circuit.

rule_checks.loc: p.1, Overview ("peak demand of 75 MW or more at a single site")
rule_checks.criteria_text: Large Load Interconnection Process is framed around a single-site large load. If multiple POIs/sites are being considered, treat them as separate screening tracks and expect additional coordination/study overhead.

rule_checks.loc: p.2, Overview ("applied to both stand-alone large load customers and those co-locating with existing or planned generation")
rule_checks.criteria_text: Large Load Interconnection Process explicitly includes large loads co-locating with existing or planned generation; such configurations can increase coordination and study dependency in screening.

rule_checks.loc: pp.2–4, Overview (Texas SB6 Net Metering Review; "net metering arrangement"; "must also obtain approval" before load can be energized)
rule_checks.criteria_text: If an export/net-metering posture is contemplated (often implying co-located generation/storage), a Net Metering Review may apply; for certain arrangements involving existing stand-alone Generation/ESR, approval through the Net Metering Review is required before the load can be energized (bounded screening signal).

rule_checks.loc: p.6, "initiate the Large Load Interconnection Process?"
rule_checks.criteria_text: Large Load interconnection begins with submission to the responsible TSP including peak demand and requested energization date.

rule_checks.loc: p.7, Planning Guide Section 9.2.2
rule_checks.criteria_text: Interconnecting Large Load must provide a preliminary Load Commissioning Plan specifying load increments and timeline to peak demand.

rule_checks.loc: p.7, Planning Guide Section 9.2.2 fee requirement
rule_checks.criteria_text: Large Load must pay an ERCOT application fee in addition to TSP fees.

rule_checks.loc: p.7, Planning Guide Section 9.2.3
rule_checks.criteria_text: Material project changes (load type, timeline acceleration, POI change, control changes) may require full or partial re-study.

rule_checks.loc: p.8–9, "What types of reliability studies are required?"
rule_checks.criteria_text: Required studies include steady-state, dynamic/transient stability, and system protection (short-circuit) analysis.

rule_checks.loc: p.10–11, Planning Guide Section 9.3.4.1
rule_checks.criteria_text: A load becomes must-study after completion of LLIS and execution of required agreements and financial security.

rule_checks.loc: p.13, Planning Guide Sections 9.5–9.6
rule_checks.criteria_text: Before energization, all LLIS studies must be completed, agreements executed, financial security provided, and commissioning plan submitted.

rule_checks.loc: p.12–13, "Network Operations Model"
rule_checks.criteria_text: Load must be included in ERCOT Network Operations Model before energization.

rule_checks.loc: p.14–15, "voltage and frequency ride-through risks"
rule_checks.criteria_text: Large Electronic Loads must meet voltage and frequency ride-through standards or may be subject to curtailment.

rule_checks.loc: p.15, Planning Guide Section 9.4(10)
rule_checks.criteria_text: If energization requirements are not met within 365 days of requested energization date used for LLIS, TSP must determine whether re-studies are required.

rule_checks.loc: p.16, Planning Guide Sections 9.2.2 & 9.6
rule_checks.criteria_text: Large load must maintain consumption within Load Commissioning Plan limits; exceeding requires notification and approval.

rule_checks.loc: Section 1.1, p.1
rule_checks.criteria_text: Applies to interconnections at transmission voltages (69 kV and higher).

rule_checks.loc: Section 3.4.1, p.3
rule_checks.criteria_text: Transmission voltages are 69 kV, 138 kV, and 345 kV. Not all voltages may be available at a given location.

rule_checks.loc: Section 3.4.1, p.3 ("The actual voltage for a Point of Delivery will be determined through analyses"; "Not all voltages may be available")
rule_checks.criteria_text: If both 138 kV and 345 kV are being considered as options, the actual POD voltage must be determined through Company analyses and availability may constrain choices.

rule_checks.loc: Section 3.4.1, p.3 ("The actual voltage for a Point of Delivery will be determined through analyses"; "Not all voltages may be available")
rule_checks.criteria_text: If both 69 kV and 138 kV are being considered as options, the actual POD voltage must be determined through Company analyses and availability may constrain choices.

rule_checks.loc: Section 3.4.1, p.3 ("The actual voltage for a Point of Delivery will be determined through analyses"; "Not all voltages may be available")
rule_checks.criteria_text: If both 69 kV and 345 kV are being considered as options, the actual POD voltage must be determined through Company analyses and availability may constrain choices.

rule_checks.loc: Section 4.1.8, p.6
rule_checks.criteria_text: Customer must provide initial and five-year load projections including peak load power factor.

rule_checks.loc: Section 4.1.6, p.6
rule_checks.criteria_text: Customer must submit a one-line electrical diagram of proposed facilities (initial and ultimate).

rule_checks.loc: Section 5.2.1, p.7
rule_checks.criteria_text: Customer protective equipment must be fully rated to interrupt available fault current.

rule_checks.loc: Section 3.6.1, p.3–4
rule_checks.criteria_text: Metering of service at each Point of Delivery is required.

rule_checks.loc: Section 3.3.2, p.3
rule_checks.criteria_text: ERCOT approval via NOMCR process is required before connecting new or modified transmission facilities.

rule_checks.loc: p.3, "may not proceed until written approval"
rule_checks.criteria_text: Initial energization may not proceed until written approval of the form is given by ERCOT.

sources.loc: PDF p.3 (written approval required before energization)

evidence: ERCOT written approval of the Energization Request form prior to energization (form p.3)
Signed/attested Energization Request form submitted to ERCOT (form p.3)
memo_guidance.what_to_do: Submit the Energization Request form and obtain ERCOT written approval before proceeding to initial energization.

rule_checks.loc: p.1, "already energized are covered by a different form"
rule_checks.criteria_text: Form applies to new energizations only; peak demand increases require a different form.

rule_checks.loc: p.2, "All studies required per the Large Load Interconnection Study process have been completed and approved"
rule_checks.criteria_text: All studies required per the LLIS process must be completed and approved per Planning Guide Section 9.4.

sources.loc: PDF p.2 (TSP confirms LLIS studies completed and approved by ERCOT)

evidence: Energization Request form attestation that all required LLIS studies have been completed and approved by ERCOT (form p.2)

rule_checks.loc: ERCOT-Large-Load-Batch-Study-Workshop-02032026.pptx, Slide 5 (background) and Slide 8 (batch process overview); PUCT Open Meeting presentation planned for 2026-02-20.
rule_checks.criteria_text: ERCOT is replacing the current individualized TSP-led LLIS model with an ERCOT-led Batch Study Process. The framework — presented at the Feb 3 2026 workshop and submitted to PUCT at the Feb 20 Open Meeting — is still preliminary and subject to change (Slide 2). The transitional Batch Zero process (Zero A and Zero B) will handle all projects currently in queue; Batch 1+ (every 6 months) will apply to new entrants. Projects entering the study process now must monitor PUCT rule 58481 finalization and ERCOT batch admission criteria. TIME ANCHORS (source: Workshop Slides 22, 24, 12-13; preliminary per Slide 2 disclaimer): Batch Zero A — case conditioning Feb–Mar 31 2026, study results communicated by Jun 15 2026; Batch Zero B — case conditioning Jun 1–Sept 1 2026, results by Jan 15 2027; Ongoing Batch 1+ — 6-month cadence (Timeline 1: results Jul 31; Timeline 2: results Jan 31); missing a batch cycle adds approximately 6 months to the study completion date.

rule_checks.loc: ERCOT-Large-Load-Batch-Study-Workshop-02032026.pptx, Slide 12-13 (Ongoing Batch Study Timeline Considerations; 6-month cadence).
rule_checks.criteria_text: The Batch Study Process runs on a 6-month cadence (Workshop Slide 12-13). Two annual cycles: Timeline 1 — case conditioning Jan 1–Apr 1, results communicated Jul 31, IA deadline Aug 31; Timeline 2 — Jul 1–Oct 1, results Jan 31, IA deadline Feb 28. If batch_cycle_window is known (e.g., "2026Q3" = Timeline 2), the memo can advise on the specific intake deadline and commitment date. Missing a cycle adds ~6 months. TIME ANCHORS for batch_cycle_window interpretation (source: Workshop Slide 13; preliminary per Slide 2 disclaimer): if a project targets Timeline 1 of a given year, the study results date is Jul 31 of that year and the IA commitment deadline is Aug 31; if it targets Timeline 2, the study results date is Jan 31 of the following year and the IA commitment deadline is Feb 28. Example: a project entering Timeline 2 of 2026 (batch_cycle_window='2026-H2') receives results by Jan 31 2027 with IA deadline Feb 28 2027. A project that misses Timeline 2 of 2026 must wait for Timeline 1 of 2027 (results Jul 31 2027), adding approximately 6 months.

rule_checks.loc: ERCOT-Large-Load-Batch-Study-Workshop-02032026.pptx, Slide 15-16 (Batch Zero is a bridge; Zero A qualification criteria).
rule_checks.criteria_text: Batch Zero A includes a "firm" path (no load allocation assessment) for projects that: (a) are operational/approved to energize (~8.2 GW), (b) were exempt from interim LLI and included in RPG/RTP study with energization before Oct 1 2027 (~17.4 GW), (c) met approved SS study + IA by Dec 15 2025 (~4.7 GW), or (d) completed PG 9.4 and 9.5 before Jan 28 2026 (~8.5 GW). If batch_zero_eligible=true, the project enters Zero A as firm load (no allocation reduction risk). If batch_zero_eligible=false or null, the project enters as "subject to load allocation" or must reapply for Batch 1.

rule_checks.loc: ERCOT-Large-Load-Batch-Study-Workshop-02032026.pptx, Slide 2 (disclaimer), Slide 47-48 (next steps); PUCT Open Meeting 2026-02-20.
rule_checks.criteria_text: As of Feb 26 2026, the Batch Study framework has been presented to PUCT at the Feb 20 Open Meeting but is still preliminary (Slide 2 disclaimer: "All information included in this presentation is preliminary and subject to change"). Workshop #3 is scheduled today. Current LLI process (Planning Guide Section 9) remains in effect. Projects should follow PG Sec 9 until ERCOT announces formal transition date (Slide 47).

rule_checks.loc: ERCOT-Large-Load-Batch-Study-Workshop-02032026.pptx, Slide 36-37 (Load Allocation Methodology — SCOPF-based); Slide 16 (Zero A/B capacity by sub-batch).
rule_checks.criteria_text: Under the Batch Study Process, load allocation is determined by Security Constrained Optimal Power Flow (SCOPF), not by queue position. ERCOT assigns dispatch costs to load requests and runs SCOPF to minimize constraint violations (Slide 36). Projects with higher shift factors on constrained elements receive lower allocations. Once queue_position is known relative to the batch, the memo can assess relative exposure. Load allocation can be reduced from prior allocations if commitment requirements (PUCT 58481 IA) are not met by the next batch start.

rule_checks.loc: p.1, M-A022326-01 – LONG DESCRIPTION: "Effective immediately, ERCOT requires TSPs to include a no-solar scenario as part of LLIS for Large Loads proposing to interconnect within the list of counties identified in this Market Notice."
rule_checks.criteria_text: ERCOT market notice M-A022326-01 requires TSPs to include a no-solar scenario as part of LLIS for Large Loads in the Far West Texas identified counties. This constraint applies only to projects with a Far West Texas POI (request.region=far_west) and results in more conservative study outcomes — higher identified upgrade costs and longer resolution timelines.

rule_checks.loc: p.1, M-A022326-01 – LONG DESCRIPTION: "ERCOT considers the identification of this risk to be a material change that impacts one or more LLIS study assumptions for interconnection requests in the identified counties." Per PG §9.4(8).
rule_checks.criteria_text: For Far West Texas projects (region=far_west): ERCOT study assumptions include the no-solar regional generation mix scenario. If the assumed generation fleet changes materially during or after the study period (e.g., additional solar retires or new thermal resources are added), study results may need to be revisited under updated assumptions. ERCOT explicitly treated the no-solar scenario identification as a material change per PG §9.4(8).

rule_checks.loc: p.1, PUCT Project No. 58481, docket filing (Sierra Club comments on 2nd Discussion Draft, 16 TAC §25.194, Jan 9 2026 workshop); rulemaking ongoing
rule_checks.criteria_text: PUCT Project No. 58481 is an active rulemaking proceeding that may result in changes to the regulatory framework governing Large Load Interconnection in Texas. Projects with long timelines should monitor this proceeding; final rules may modify planning obligations, fees, or process steps not yet reflected in the current Planning Guide.

rule_checks.loc: p.1-3, PUCT Project No. 58481, docket (16 TAC §25.194) — rulemaking establishing new interconnection standards for large loads; corroborated by ERCOT Q&A Rev.12.15.25 ("PUC is in the process of establishing new interconnection standards for large loads in Project No. 58481")
rule_checks.criteria_text: Pending PUCT regulatory changes may alter Large Load interconnection obligations including but not limited to: study timelines, fee structures, agreement terms, and TSP responsibilities. Projects in early-stage planning should explicitly track PUCT Project 58481 for potential impacts to their interconnection schedule.

rule_checks.loc: Rev.12.15.25, p.14 ("PUC is in the process of establishing new interconnection standards for large loads in Project No. 58481. That rulemaking could require changes to ERCOT's large load interconnection process and delay projects that must meet new requirements.")
rule_checks.criteria_text: Under Texas SB6 and the revised Large Load Q&A (Rev. 12.15.25): if an export/net-metering arrangement is contemplated, approval through the Net Metering Review is required before the load can be energized. This requirement applies to certain co-located arrangements with existing or planned generation/ESR (bounded screening signal; final applicability depends on metering arrangements).

rule_checks.loc: p.1, M-A122325-01 (batch study process announcement, Dec 23 2025; PGRR115 already insufficient; batch study as successor framework)
rule_checks.criteria_text: ERCOT announced on Dec 23, 2025 (M-A122325-01) that PGRR115, implemented Dec 15, 2025, is already insufficient to manage the volume of large load requests. ERCOT is developing a new "Batch Study process" as a successor framework. Projects submitted after this announcement should be evaluated against the batch study timeline and process rules rather than the pre-batch LLIS process alone.

rule_checks.loc: Rev.12.15.25, p.2 ("The interim process has applied to both stand-alone large load customers and those co-locating with existing or planned generation.")
rule_checks.criteria_text: The revised Large Load Q&A (Rev. 12.15.25) continues to explicitly include co-located loads (with existing or planned generation) within the LLIS applicability scope. Co-located configurations carry elevated coordination and study dependency.

rule_checks.loc: Slide 5-7, ERCOT-Large-Load-Batch-Studies-LLWG_01222026.pptx (Slide 5: Transitional Batch Zero and restudy context; Slide 7: TSP role changes impacting in-progress LLI requests during batch transition)
rule_checks.criteria_text: Under the proposed batch study process, a material change to an in-queue project (e.g., POI change, load increase, timeline acceleration) may cause the project to be re-slotted into a subsequent batch cycle rather than being re-studied individually. This can compound timeline delays beyond what the current individualized re-study framework implies.

rule_checks.loc: p.1, M-A122325-01 – LONG DESCRIPTION: structural challenges including "coordination across TSPs, repeated restudies, and a growing backlog." Also corroborated by Q&A Rev.12.15.25 p.10: "A common reason re-studies are needed is that another large load customer in the same area becomes a must-study load."
rule_checks.criteria_text: Under the batch study framework, the entry of a large number of must-study projects in the same geographic cohort can delay all cohort members simultaneously – analogous to the existing re-study risk in the individualized process (LL_QA_010) but potentially affecting larger groups of projects at once.

rule_checks.loc: p.1, M-A122325-03 (Jan 30, 2026): draft framework posted for Feb 3 workshop; feedback deadline Feb 5; sets up Feb 12 second workshop; framework to be filed at Feb 20 PUC Open Meeting.
rule_checks.criteria_text: ERCOT market notice series M-A122325 (notices -01 through -05) collectively announce the policy direction toward a Batch Study Process. Individually, each notice may update process details, timelines, or requirements. Projects should track the full series to avoid acting on superseded notice provisions.

rule_checks.loc: p.1, M-A122325-05 (Feb 17, 2026): "PUC recently provided guidance to ERCOT and stakeholders to engage in an expedited process to develop revision requests that create a new Batch Zero study for consideration at the June 1, 2026 ERCOT Board meeting."
rule_checks.criteria_text: ERCOT Market Notice M-A122325-05 is the latest in the M-A122325 series as of 2026-02-26. It may contain the most current batch study process details, timelines, or eligibility criteria announced prior to the final rule. Projects assessing study timeline risk should reference this notice for the most recent ERCOT policy position.

rule_checks.loc: p.1, M-A122325-01 (context: public reporting of ERCOT shift to data-center batch study framework)
rule_checks.criteria_text: ERCOT is transitioning from individualized Large Load studies to a batch study process, partly in response to a surge in data center and large-load interconnection requests. This macro shift means projects submitted in the near term may face a different study process than projects submitted under the current framework, creating planning uncertainty for any project with a 2026-2028 energization target.

rule_checks.loc: p.1, M-A022326-01 – LONG DESCRIPTION: "ERCOT will not approve LLIS studies for Large Load additions in the Far West unless they include a no-solar scenario." Counties: Andrews, Borden, Brewster, Coke, Concho, Crane, Crockett, Culberson, Dawson, Ector, Edwards, Fisher, Glasscock, Howard, Irion, Jeff Davis, Jones, Kinney, Loving, Lynn, Martin, Midland, Mitchell, Nolan, Pecos, Presidio, Reagan, Reeves, Schleicher, Scurry, Sterling, Sutton, Terrell, Tom Green, Upton, Val Verde, Ward, Winkler.
rule_checks.criteria_text: For Far West Texas projects (region=far_west): the no-solar scenario constraint typically produces higher identified upgrade costs and longer resolution timelines compared to projects in other ERCOT zones — even for similar load sizes and configurations. This is a direct consequence of M-A022326-01 requirements.

rule_checks.loc: p.1, M-A022326-01 – ACTION REQUIRED: "TSPs for Large Loads requesting to interconnect within the identified counties that have LLIS studies that are not started or are currently in progress, as well as studies approved under §9.4 but where ILLE has not met §9.5 requirements as of 2026-02-23, must update the study to include a no-solar scenario."
rule_checks.criteria_text: For Far West Texas projects (region=far_west) where LLIS is already complete: ERCOT study results may be conditional on the no-solar scenario. If ILLE has not yet met §9.5 requirements as of 2026-02-23, the study must be updated per M-A022326-01. Even after §9.5 satisfaction, system-level assumption changes (new or retired regional generation) could trigger restudy before energization.

rule_checks.loc: p.1, PUCT Project No. 58481, docket (Sierra Club comments reference 50% backup generation threshold, SB 6 compliance, and large load qualification standards under 16 TAC §25.194)
rule_checks.criteria_text: Pending PUCT rulemaking under Project 58481 may modify energization prerequisites, TSP/ILLE obligations, or ERCOT approval authority for Large Load projects. Projects targeting energization in 2026-2028 should confirm that their energization checklist reflects any adopted rule changes before finalizing the readiness assessment.

rule_checks.loc: ERCOT-Large-Load-Batch-Study-Workshop-02032026.pptx, Slide 16 (Batch Zero A and Zero B qualification and anticipated capacity); Slide 18 (Inclusion Criteria for Batch Zero A).
rule_checks.criteria_text: Batch Zero A qualification (Slide 18): A project is included as FIRM (no allocation assessment) if it: (a) is operational or approved to energize (~8,223 MW); (b) was exempt from interim LLI process and included in RPG/RTP study with energization before Oct 1, 2027 (~17,437 MW); (c) met approved steady-state study + signed IA to be designated 'must study' under interim LLI process before Dec 15, 2025 (~4,666 MW); or (d) fulfilled PG 9.4 (all LLIS studies complete) and PG 9.5 (agreements, financial security, NTP) before Jan 28, 2026 (~8,471 MW). Projects that have started LLI study process but do not meet the above criteria are NOT included in Batch Zero A (~59,411 MW affected). batch_zero_eligible=true indicates the project qualifies as firm; batch_zero_eligible=false means it must enter as 'subject to load allocation' in Zero B or reapply for Batch 1.

rule_checks.loc: ERCOT-Large-Load-Batch-Study-Workshop-02032026.pptx, Slide 19-24 (Batch Zero B inclusion criteria; Slide 22 Zero A timeline; Slide 24 Zero B timeline).
rule_checks.criteria_text: Batch Zero B timeline (Slide 24): Case conditioning Jun 1–Sept 1 2026. Deadline for LLI to meet 58481 intermediate agreement requirements: Aug 1 2026. Results communicated Jan 15 2027. Deadline for ILLE to meet 58481 interconnection agreement requirements for load allocation to be firm in Batch 1: Feb 28 2027. Batch Zero A results deadline: Jun 15 2026 (Slide 22). Deadline for firm allocation in Batch Zero B: Aug 1 2026 (IA required). If a project's batch_zero_eligible=false and it has a COD target in 2027 or later, it must meet the 58481 intermediate agreement requirements before Aug 1 2026 to be included in Batch Zero B as 'subject to load allocation'; otherwise it must reapply for Batch 1. TIME ANCHORS — minimum study timeline floor by scenario (source: Slides 22, 24; all dates preliminary per Slide 2 disclaimer): (1) batch_zero_eligible=true → study results by Jun 15 2026 (Batch Zero A), floor from today (2026-02-27) ≈ 4 months to study results; add 6–12 months for agreements + NTP + NOM → earliest realistic energization floor ≈ late 2026 to early 2027. (2) batch_zero_eligible=false, IA submitted before Aug 1 2026 → study results Jan 15 2027 (Batch Zero B), floor ≈ 10.5 months to study results; add 6–12 months → earliest realistic energization floor ≈ mid to late 2027. (3) batch_zero_eligible=false, IA not submitted before Aug 1 2026 → must enter Batch 1 (Timeline 1 2027: results Jul 31 2027, or Timeline 2 2027: results Jan 31 2028); floor ≈ 17–23 months to study results; add 6–12 months → earliest realistic energization floor ≈ 2028 or later. These floors are study-process floors only; transmission upgrade construction timelines (if triggered) extend COD further and are not captured here.
